Award.AwardTitle: LTREB Renewal: Collaborative Research: Density-Dependent and Density-Independent Effects on the Non-Breeding Season Dynamics of a Migratory Bird
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project continues a 25-year study of long-distance migratory birds during the non-breeding season in Jamaica. Over the next five years, the researchers will measure how birds' physical condition and survival are influenced by population size and climate. Survival is expected to decrease as population size increases, a phenomenon known as regulation. However, survival also responds to factors such as weather that act independently of population size, a process known as limitation. Understanding how population regulation and limitation influence survival and abundance is necessary to predict how future environmental change will affect migratory birds. Since climatologists forecast increasing drought in the Caribbean, results from this research will provide critical insights into the consequences of climate change on the behavior, abundance, and ultimately the evolution of these species.

This project will facilitate the professional training of two graduate and over 20 undergraduate students in the US, as well as Jamaican students and scientists. The investigators will continue their existing collaborations with Jamaican wildlife agencies and local conservation groups, and will communicate their research results to scientists, policy makers, and citizens in the U.S. and the Caribbean. Data from the project are available electronically.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to test hypotheses concerning ecological factors limiting and controlling populations of migratory birds in the non-breeding (wintering) season in the New World tropics (focused on Jamaica), including effects of bird population density, food needed for survival and migration, and rainfall, which varies in the Caribbean region with El Niño-LaNiña climate cycles and influences food availability. The intellectual findings of this study are multiple: (1) We refined the ability to track and analyze animal movements and distributions in 3D. This included modifying existing measures of 2D spatial (e.g., territorial) overlap to 3D and showing that spatial overlap, and thus potential competition for space and food, is different in 3D versus 2D. (2) We experimentally manipulated food available to adult male American redstarts to demonstrate a tradeoff in maintaining lipid (fat) versus muscle mass tissues, and a biologically meaningful delay in migration timing due to the loss of flight muscle mass prior to Spring migration north to North America. (3) We demonstrated that transient (non-territorial) individuals are a hitherto unappreciated component of the wintering birds, even in habitats with abundant territorial individuals, and we developed a robust statistical method to count, and identify (by age and sex) these transient individuals in the wintering population. Moreover, the number of such transient individuals varies in space and time, being more frequent in coastal compared to inland habitats, and more frequent right after a hurricane damaged south coast Jamaican habitats. (4) We demonstrated population regulation (i.e., control) for the first time in a wintering population of migratory bird, i.e., negative effects of population density, and at multiple spatial scales as well as to different degrees in different habitats. Population regulation in these birds is linked to food abundance, which varies among winter habitats, and over time (e.g., in relation to El Niño-La Niña climate cycles). (5) We have obtained compelling evidence that population limitation in wintering migrant bird populations is also influenced by inter-specific (between-species) competition for food, both involving resident birds and other wintering migrant bird species. Based on detailed diet data, this competition among wintering migrants occurs in multiple habitats, including shaded coffee plantations, black mangroves (and adjacent thorn-scrub habitats), and inland wet limestone habitats. The diet data indicate what we have termed the “paradox of the diets”, namely that these wintering migrants are opportunistic in diet, overlapping considerably, which probably intensifies the competition among species; but different species also feed on distinctive prey types linked to their morphologies and feeding behaviors (e.g., foraging microhabitats) that contribute to the coexistence of these species in winter habitats in which food competition can be intense. Understanding inter-specific competition is important to determine how multiple species abundances are simultaneously limited on the wintering grounds, and how changing climate and other impacts on habitat quality in winter may affect future populations. (6) Our results also indicate that these migratory bird populations are likely limited simultaneously in winter via adult survival and summer via reproductive success, which latter fluctuates greatly from year-to-year. Nesting success influences population fluctuations primarily in relation to nest predator populations in breeding American redstarts, and nest predation is in turn influenced indirectly by summer food abundance. (7) Preliminary information suggests that the breeding population of American redstarts varies genetically across the breeding range, which if verified in future research has implications for population connectivity (how birds move between wintering and breeding geographic ranges), natal (from birth) dispersal, and population limitation and regulation in such long-distance migratory birds.

 

The broader impacts of this study include training 1 post-doctoral researcher, 5 Ph.D. students, and 30 undergraduate or recent graduate students as field assistants or laboratory techs. Additionally this research contributed to the updating of two species accounts (American redstart, black-throated blue warbler) in the authoritative series Birds of North America online, an indispensable tool for avian research generally; and to a new chapter on foods and foraging in an important ornithology reference work (Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology's Handbook of Bird Biology, 3rd Edition). Our work has also contributed to web sites for public education and outreach, including the Migratory Bird Center of the Smithsonian Institution; and to many new collaborations for ongoing and future studies of population limitation, regulation, and community structure. This project also resulted in dozens of scientific publications on the topics described above, with many more in progress.
